'''Talk Talk''' were an English band formed in 1981, led by [[Mark Hollis]] (vocals, guitar, piano), [[Lee Harris (drummer)|Lee Harris]] (drums), and [[Paul Webb]] (bass). The group achieved early chart success with the [[synth-pop]] singles "[[Talk Talk (Talk Talk song)|Talk Talk]]" (1982), "[[It's My Life (Talk Talk song)|It's My Life]]", and "[[Such a Shame]]" (both 1984) before moving towards a more experimental approach informed by jazz and free improvisation in the mid-1980s,<ref name="Phillips"/> pioneering what became known as [[post-rock]].<ref name="chutlerB" /> Talk Talk achieved widespread critical success in Europe and the UK with the singles "[[Life's What You Make It (Talk Talk song)|Life's What You Make It]]" (1985) and "[[Living in Another World]]" (1986); in 1988, they released their fourth album ''[[Spirit of Eden]]'', which was critically acclaimed but commercially unsuccessful.

Friction with the band's [[Record label|label]], [[EMI Records|EMI]], resulted in legal action and countersuing. Webb departed, and the band switched to [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] for their final studio album, 1991's ''[[Laughing Stock (album)|Laughing Stock]]'', but split soon afterwards. Singer [[Mark Hollis (musician)|Mark Hollis]] released one solo album in 1998 before retiring from the music industry; he died in 2019. The band's founding bass player and drummer, Paul Webb and Lee Harris, played in several bands together; long-term collaborator [[Tim Friese-Greene]] continued in the business as a musician and producer.

== History ==

=== 1981–1983: Formation ===

Talk Talk began as a quartet consisting of [[Mark Hollis]], formerly from The Reaction (vocals/main songwriter), [[Lee Harris (drummer)|Lee Harris]] (drums), [[Paul Webb]] (bass guitar), and Simon Brenner (keyboards). In their early years they were often compared with [[Duran Duran]]. In addition to a band name consisting of a repeated word, the two shared a [[Roxy Music]]-inspired musical direction, as well as the same record label ([[EMI]]) and producer ([[Colin Thurston]]). The band also supported Duran Duran on tour in late 1981.

The band released their first single, "Mirror Man", on EMI in February 1982. The single was not a great success, but was quickly followed by their [[Talk Talk (Talk Talk song)|self-titled single]] in April 1982 (a rerecording of a track by The Reaction) which reached No. 52 in the UK. The band's first album, titled ''[[The Party's Over (Talk Talk album)|The Party's Over]]'', was released in July 1982. The band had their first UK [[Top 40]] hits with the singles "[[Today (Talk Talk song)|Today]]" (UK No. 14) and a re-release of "[[Talk Talk (Talk Talk song)|Talk Talk]]" (UK No. 23). These singles also were hits in other countries including Ireland, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. The re-release of the "Talk Talk" single reached the U.S. Top 75. The album was produced by [[Colin Thurston]], who was [[Duran Duran]]'s in-house EMI producer at the time, but picked by Hollis because of his involvement with [[David Bowie]]'s ''[[Heroes (David Bowie album)|Heroes]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Seabrook|first=Thomas Jerome|title=Bowie in Berlin: A New Career in a New Town|date=February 2008|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsSHjTf_-F8C&pg=PA250|publisher=Jawbone|isbn=978-1-906002-08-4|pages=250–51}}</ref> It was a moderate success in the UK reaching No. 21, and was later certified Silver by the [[British Phonographic Industry|BPI]] for sales of 60,000 copies by 1985. It was a Top 10 hit in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://charts.nz/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=The+Party%27s+Over&cat=a|work=charts.nz|publisher=Hung Medien / eMedia Jungden|title=Talk Talk – The Party's Over (Album)|year=2011|access-date=31 December 2011}}</ref>

Brenner left after the 1983 non-LP hit single "My Foolish Friend", which was produced by frequent [[Roxy Music]] collaborator [[Rhett Davies]]. At this point, Talk Talk was now a trio, as Brenner was never officially replaced. However, [[Tim Friese-Greene]] was recruited to assist with the recording of their second album, ''[[It's My Life (album)|It's My Life]]'',<ref name="tape">{{cite book|last1=Crane|first1=Larry|last2=Eckman|first2=Chris|editor=Larry Crane|title=Tape Op: The Book about Creative Music Recording, Volume 2|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=foViXo_JV9YC&pg=PA74|year=2010|publisher=Hal Leonard|isbn=978-0-9779903-0-6|pages=74–77|chapter=Sharing food and conversation with Phil Brown}}</ref> and he became the band's producer as well as keyboardist and Hollis' songwriting partner. Although a major contributor to the band's studio output and a de facto fourth member,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/27/obituaries/mark-hollis-dies.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=28 February 2019|title=Mark Hollis, Leader of '80s Band Talk Talk, Is Dead|first=Daniel E.|last=Slotnik|date=27 February 2019}}</ref> Friese-Greene never officially joined the band.  As such, he did not play with the touring band on live dates, and was absent from the band's publicity material.

=== 1984–1986: Commercial success ===

Although major success eluded them in the UK, Talk Talk achieved considerable international success in 1984/85, particularly in continental Europe, North America and New Zealand, with the album ''[[It's My Life (album)|It's My Life]]''. The accompanying single "Such a Shame" (inspired by the book ''[[The Dice Man]]'') became a Top 10 hit in Austria,<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=Such+A+Shame&cat=s |title=Talk Talk – Such A Shame |publisher=austriancharts.at |access-date=4 February 2010}}</ref> Italy, France, Germany, [[Netherlands]] and [[Switzerland]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://hitparade.ch/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=Such+A+Shame&cat=s |title=Talk Talk – Such A Shame |publisher=hitparade.ch |access-date=4 February 2010}}</ref> during this period. The title track of the album entered the U.S., Canadian, French, German, New Zealand<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=https://charts.nz/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=It%27s+My+Life&cat=s |title=Talk Talk – It's My Life |publisher=charts.nz |access-date=4 February 2010}}</ref> and Netherlands<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://dutchcharts.nl/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=It%27s+My+Life&cat=s |title=Talk Talk – It's My Life |publisher=dutchcharts.nl |access-date=4 February 2010}}</ref> Top 40. A third single, "Dum Dum Girl", was a success in some European countries and in New Zealand;<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://hitparade.ch/showitem.asp?interpret=Talk+Talk&titel=Dum+Dum+Girl&cat=s |title=Talk Talk – Dum Dum Girl |website=Hitparade.ch |access-date=11 March 2016}}</ref> however, the album and its singles were largely ignored in the UK. Commercial success notwithstanding, the band made deliberate choices that moved them away from the mainstream. The music video for "It's My Life", for instance, featured a grumpy Hollis who mocks lip-synching; after EMI protested, they re-shot the video, turning it into "a total piss-take of lip-synching", in [[Alan McGee]]'s words.<ref name="McGee">{{cite news |last=McGee |first=Alan |title=Wherefore art thou Mark Hollis |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=9 April 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/apr/09/markhollis}}</ref>

The artist [[James Marsh (artist)|James Marsh]] designed the first cover image for ''It's My Life'' based on the band's name. He followed the theme for subsequent singles, remaining the band's artistic frontman and creating all their covers and posters throughout their career.

Talk Talk abandoned the synthpop style completely with their third album, 1986's ''[[The Colour of Spring]]''. It became their biggest success in the UK, making the Top 10 (and certified Gold by the BPI for sales over 100,000 copies), in part due to the Top 20 single "[[Life's What You Make It (Talk Talk song)|Life's What You Make It]]", which was also successful internationally.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://hitparade.ch/song/Talk-Talk/Life's-What-You-Make-It-1390 |title=Talk Talk – Life's What You Make It |website=Hitparade.ch |access-date=16 June 2017}}</ref> Another single, "[[Living in Another World]]", charted in the Top 40 in Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium and Italy (and just outside the Top 40 in the UK and France). By this time, all Talk Talk songs were being written by Hollis and Friese-Greene. The extended line-up for the 1986 tour consisted of Hollis, Webb and Harris, plus [[John Turnbull (musician)|John Turnbull]] (guitars), Rupert Black and Ian Curnow (keyboards), Phil Reis and Leroy Williams (percussion), and [[Mark Feltham (musician)|Mark Feltham]] (harmonica). Most notable among these concerts was their appearance at the [[Montreux Jazz Festival]], 11 July 1986, released on DVD in 2008 as ''[[Live at Montreux 1986]]''.

=== 1987–1991: Experimental period ===

The success of ''The Colour of Spring'' afforded the band a bigger budget and schedule for the recording of their next album. Over a year in the making, and featuring contributions from many outside musicians, ''[[Spirit of Eden]]'' was released in 1988, on EMI's [[Parlophone]] label. The album was assembled from many hours of improvised instrumentation that Hollis and Friese-Greene had edited and arranged using digital equipment. The result was a mix of rock, jazz, classical, and ambient music. Critically praised, the album reached the UK Top 20 and was certified Silver by the BPI for sales of over 60,000 copies. The band announced they would not be attempting to recreate the album live (since, according to Hollis, "People would just want to hear the songs as they are on the album and for me that's not satisfying enough"). Without touring or music videos or singles as the band intended, there was little marketing left that the record company could do; in the end the band grudgingly agreed to a video for the remixed version of "[[I Believe in You (Talk Talk song)|I Believe in You]]", released as first single. Hollis, though, was unhappy with the video, as he made clear in an interview with ''[[Q Magazine]]'': "I really feel that [the video] was a massive mistake ... I thought just by sitting there and listening and really thinking about what it was about, I could get that in my eyes. But you cannot do it. It just feels stupid. It was depressing and I wish I'd never done it."<ref name="deevoy">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/28/from-rocks-backpages-talk-talk|title=Talk Talk: 'You should never listen to music as background music' – a classic interview from the vaults|last=Deevoy|first=Adrian|date=28 August 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=25 September 2013}}</ref>

During the making of ''Spirit of Eden'', Talk Talk manager Keith Aspden had attempted to free the band from their record contract with EMI. "I knew by that time that EMI was not the company this band should be with," Aspden said. "I was fearful that the money wouldn't be there to record another album."> EMI, however, wished to keep the band on their roster.  After many months of litigation, the band ultimately succeeded in extracting themselves from the contract. EMI then sued the band, claiming that ''Spirit of Eden'' was not "commercially satisfactory", but the case was thrown out of court.<ref name="McGee"/> Webb left the band in late 1988.

With the band now released from EMI, the label released the retrospective compilation ''[[Natural History: The Very Best of Talk Talk|Natural History]]'' in 1990. It peaked at number 3 on the UK album chart and was certified Gold by the BPI for sales of over 100,000 copies. It was also an international success and eventually went on to sell more than 1 million copies worldwide. The 1984 single "It's My Life" was also re-released, and this time became the band's highest charting single in their native country, reaching number 13 on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. A re-release of the single "Life's What You Make It" also reached the Top 30. Following up on this renewed popular interest in the band, the label then released ''[[History Revisited]]'' in 1991, a compilation of new remixes, which made the UK Top 40 (it also reached the Top 30 in Germany and the Top 75 in the Netherlands). The band sued EMI for releasing the remixed material without their permission.<ref name="McGee"/><ref>Buckley, Peter. "The rough guide to rock". Rough Guides, 2003. vii. {{ISBN|1-84353-105-4}}</ref>

By 1990 the band had essentially morphed into a vehicle for the studio recordings of Hollis and long-term collaborator Friese-Greene, along with session musicians (including long-term Talk Talk drummer Harris). The group signed a two-album contract with [[Polydor Records]] and released ''[[Laughing Stock (album)|Laughing Stock]]'' on Polydor's [[Verve Records]] imprint in 1991.  ''Laughing Stock'' crystallised the experimental sound the band started with ''Spirit of Eden'' (which has been retroactively categorised as "[[post-rock]]" by some critics).<ref name=chutlerB>{{cite book|last1=Chuter|first1=Jack|title=Storm Static Sleep|date=November 2015|publisher=Function|url=http://www.peoplesbookprize.com/Extracts/i1354.extract.pdf|ref=Chuter}}</ref> Even more minimalist than its predecessor, ''Laughing Stock'' reached just No. 26 on the [[UK Albums Chart]].{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}

== Post break-up ==

After ''Laughing Stock'', Talk Talk disbanded in 1991; [[Mark Hollis|Hollis]] said that he wished to focus on his family.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2011/feb/28/talk-talk-mark-hollis|title=How Talk Talk spoke to today's artists|last=Myers|first=Ben|date=28 February 2012|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=25 September 2013}}</ref> Paul Webb rejoined Lee Harris, and the two went on to form the band [[.O.rang]], while Tim Friese-Greene started recording under the name [[Tim Friese-Greene|Heligoland]]. In 1998, Mark Hollis released his self-titled solo début ''[[Mark Hollis (album)|Mark Hollis]]'', which was much in keeping with the minimalist post-rock sound of ''Spirit of Eden'' and ''Laughing Stock'', but he retired from the music industry shortly afterwards.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}

Webb also collaborated under the name of [[Rustin Man]] with [[Portishead (band)|Portishead]] lead singer [[Beth Gibbons]] and released ''[[Out of Season (Beth Gibbons and Rustin Man album)|Out of Season]]'' in 2002, ''[[Drift Code]]'' in 2019 and ''Clockdust'' in 2020. Harris also featured on the [[Bark Psychosis]] 2004 album, ''[[Codename: Dustsucker|///Codename: Dustsucker]]''.

Mark Hollis died on 25 February 2019, aged 64.<ref name="NME death">{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/mark-hollis-talk-talk-reportedly-died-aged-64-2453863 |title=Talk Talk's Mark Hollis has reportedly died, aged 64 |last=Aubrey |first=Elizabeth |website=[[NME]] |date=25 February 2019 |access-date=25 February 2019 |url-status = live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2019.02.25-193941/https://www.nme.com/news/music/mark-hollis-talk-talk-reportedly-died-aged-64-2453863 |archive-date=25 February 2019 }}</ref>

== Legacy and influence ==
Talk Talk's influence upon musicians has exceeded the band's visibility among the general public. Along with the band [[Slint]], Talk Talk are credited with inventing "[[post-rock]]" in their last two albums, ''Spirit of Eden'' and ''Laughing Stock''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/explore/style/post-rock-d2682 |title=Music Genres |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=11 March 2013}}</ref> The artists who have praised the band or cited them as an influence include [[Pearl Jam]]'s [[Jeff Ament]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2021/12/5-albums-i-cant-live-without-jeff-ament-of-pearl-jam/|title=5 Albums I Can't Live Without: Jeff Ament of Pearl Jam|date=10 December 2021|website=Spin.com|access-date=17 January 2022}}</ref> [[Tears for Fears]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ePzZ55GeXiY|title=Roland Orzabal & Curt Smith - Choose their favourite 80s Tracks - Radio Broadcast 16/10/2020|access-date=17 January 2022|via=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> [[Matthew Good]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Corus Radio|title=An Evening With Matt Good – Part 1 of 2|date=24 May 2011|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGtjaWD-CF8&t=5m45s| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211118/rGtjaWD-CF8| archive-date=2021-11-18 | url-status=live|access-date=13 September 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> [[Radiohead]],<ref>
{{cite tweet|title="It redefines how you listen to music" - @Radiohead's Philip Selway on Spirit of Eden.|user=BBC6Music|date=16 September 2018|number=1041317441970884608}}</ref> [[Doves (band)|Doves]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.qthemusic.com/articles/interviews/love-enigma-talk-talk-mark-hollis-doves-jimi-goodwin-exclusive-extract|title=Why I love the enigma of Talk Talk & Mark Hollis by Doves' Jimi Goodwin - exclusive extract|last=Goodwin|first=Jimi|author-link=Jimi Goodwin|website=[[Q (magazine)|Q]]|access-date=5 March 2019}}</ref> [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2008/04/20/2008-04-20_elbow_makes_its_bones_in_seldom_seen_kid.html |title=Elbow makes its bones in 'Seldom Seen Kid' |work=Daily News|location=New York |date=19 April 2008 |access-date=11 March 2016}}</ref> [[Shearwater (band)|Shearwater]],<ref>[http://wesleyanargus.com/2012/02/02/a-body-not-just-a-brain-an-interview-with-shearwaters-jonathan-meiburg/ "A Body, Not Just a Brain": An Interview with Shearwater's Jonathan Meiburg – Arts]. The Wesleyan Argus. Retrieved 10 April 2012.</ref> [[M83 (band)|M83]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicagoinnerview.com/innerviews/m83-2/ |title=M83 |publisher=Chicago Innerview |access-date=11 March 2016}}</ref> [[Bark Psychosis]],<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | url = http://thequietus.com/articles/15990-bark-psychosis-hex-graham-sutton-interview | website = [[The Quietus]] | title = I Put A Spell on You: The Story Of Bark Psychosis & Hex | first = Wyndham | last = Wallace | date = 14 August 2014 }}</ref> [[The Notwist]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.popmatters.com/179884-from-one-wrong-place-to-the-next-an-interview-with-the-notwist-2495678209.html|last=Solis|first=Jose|title=From One Wrong Place to the Next: An Interview with The Notwist|website=[[PopMatters]]|date=12 March 2014|access-date=5 March 2019}}</ref> [[Cedric Bixler-Zavala]] of [[the Mars Volta]],<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | url = http://forum.thecomatorium.com/forum/index.php?showtopic=20371 | title = Influences | date = 25 April 2005 | quote = ''Q'': Does music sometimes make you cry?<br />''Cedric Bixler-Zavala'': Yeah definitely. [...] Talk Talk records...because you get moved by them...The last one they did, where they did a complete turnaround musically – ''Laughing Stock'' – it's a good rainy day album. I think a person in the band was getting a major divorce and you can hear it in the album. I was attracted to it to it cause the guy who told us about it told us that they recorded it with candles and stuff and it was real dark album for them and the label hated it. So instantly I was attracted to it...It's a big downer, but you know, downer music is good, though, too. | website = thecomatorium.com }}</ref> [[Steven Wilson]] of [[Porcupine Tree]],<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | url = http://www.innerviews.org/inner/wilson.html | title = Steven Wilson {{!}} Art as a mirror | date = 2012 | first = Anil | last = Prasad | author-link = Anil Prasad | website = Innerviews.org }}</ref> [[Storm Corrosion]] (a joint project between [[Opeth]]'s [[Mikael Åkerfeldt]] and Porcupine Tree's Steven Wilson),<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fQ4QTAHp8HQ | via = YouTube | publisher = [[Roadrunner Records UK]] | date = 19 April 2012 | title = Storm Corrosion – Fan Q&A – Making Something Different }}</ref> [[Steve Hogarth]] of [[Marillion]],<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | title = 10QUESTIONS with... STEVE HOGARTH (MARILLION) | website = Getreadytorock.com | url = http://www.getreadytorock.com/10questions/steve_hogarth_marillion.htm | first = David | last = Randall | date = 2004 }}</ref> [[Richard Barbieri]] of [[Japan (band)|Japan]] and Porcupine Tree,<ref>{{cite web | access-date = 28 March 2017 | url = http://www.2uptop.com/news/The-Richard-Barbieri-Interview/ | title = The Richard Barbieri Interview | first = Jim | last = Powell | website = 2uptop.com }}</ref> and [[Death Cab for Cutie]].<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uwF2s-BIA7o Death Cab For Cutie on Arcade Fire, U2 and their influences – Q25]. YouTube (28 July 2012). Retrieved 10 April 2012.</ref>

The bands [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]], [[Weezer]], [[The Divine Comedy (band)|the Divine Comedy]] and [[The Gathering (band)|the Gathering]] covered their song "Life's What You Make It" and [[No Doubt]] scored a global hit with a cover of "It's My Life" in 2003 which reached number 20 on the UK charts. [[Lights (musician)|Lights]] recorded a cover of "Living in Another World" <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YBRLqAisr_c| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211118/YBRLqAisr_c| archive-date=2021-11-18 | url-status=live|title=Lights- Living in Another World feat. Darkstars (+ Download!)|access-date=14 October 2021|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> [[Guy Garvey]] of the band Elbow said: "Mark Hollis started from punk and by his own admission he had no musical ability. To go from only having the urge, to writing some of the most timeless, intricate and original music ever is as impressive as the moon landings for me."<ref>{{cite magazine|editor1-last=Alexander|editor1-first=Phil|title=All back to my place – Guy Garvey|magazine=Mojo Magazine|date=May 2012|issue=222|page=9|publisher=Bauer|location=London|issn=1351-0193}}</ref>

A tribute album and anthological book, both titled ''Spirit of Talk Talk'', were released in 2012. The book includes all the artwork James Marsh did for the band, and hand-written lyrics (by the band). The album includes covers by various artists, proceeds going to the conservation organisation BirdLife International.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/45195-talk-talk-celebrated-with-tribute-album-book/|title=Talk Talk Celebrated With Tribute Album, Book|last=Battan|first=Carrie|date=25 January 2012|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|access-date=25 September 2013}}</ref>

On Tuesday 26 November 2019, ''Spirit of Talk Talk'' organised A Celebration of Mark Hollis and Talk Talk concert<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/talk-talk-surviving-members-reunite-show-honour-mark-hollis-2533193|title=Surviving Talk Talk musicians announce show to honour Mark Hollis|date=2019-07-29|website=NME Music News, Reviews, Videos, Galleries, Tickets and Blogs {{!}} NME.COM|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-11-28}}</ref> at the Royal Festival Hall, London, UK. Founding band member Simon Brenner, who played keyboards on studio album, ''The Party's Over'' was amongst the long list of guest musicians who performed songs from all five Talk Talk studio albums and Mark Hollis' solo album. The evening was described as ''A Majestic Tribute'' by the London-based daily newspaper The Evening Standard.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/music/mark-hollis-tribute-celebration-review-southbank-centre-a4297806.html|title=Mark Hollis tribute gig at the Southbank Centre 'majestic, complex stuff'|date=2019-11-27|website=Evening Standard|language=en|access-date=2019-11-28}}</ref>

In March 2020, a documentary about Talk Talk was screened for the first time at the [[Copenhagen International Documentary Film Festival]]. Entitled ''In a Silent Way'', filmed before Mark Hollis' death and without the participation of the main band members, it pays tribute to the musical journey and integrity of Talk Talk.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indie-eye.it/cinema/covercinema/in-a-silent-way-di-gwenael-brees-recensione.html|title=In a Silent Way (film)|website=Indie-Eye|language=it|access-date=2021-08-25}}</ref> In September 2021, the film won the prize for best music documentary awarded by the jury of the Musical Ecran festival in France.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.fr/festival-musical-ecran-decouvrez-le-palmares-de-la-7e-edition/|title=Festival Musical Écran : découvrez le palmarès de la 7e édition|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|language=fr|access-date=2021-09-15}}</ref>

Hollis and Talk Talk continue to be praised as artists who did not cave in to the pressures of corporate and commercial interests. Says [[Alan McGee]], "I find the whole story of one man against the system in a bid to maintain creative control incredibly heartening."<ref name="McGee"/>
